name: Twin prime conjecture
rephrased: There are infinitely many pairs of prime numbers that differ by two.
implication_form: If N is a positive integer, then there exists a pair of twin primes both greater than N.
posed_by: 19th-century mathematicians (attributed to observations by Euclid and formalized by figures like Alphonse de Racine)
explained: A twin prime is a prime number that is either 2 less or 2 more than another prime number, forming a pair (p, p+2) where both p and p+2 are prime. The Twin Prime Conjecture states that there are infinitely many such pairs. In other words, there are infinitely many primes p such that p+2 is also prime. This conjecture is one of the oldest unsolved problems in number theory.
